IRS Code 740 Meaning

IRS Code 740 typically means a refund was returned to the IRS as undeliverable. This page explains when it shows up on transcripts, what it usually signals, and practical next steps. Want to see what clients get? Open the sample report, then run your own transcript when you’re ready.

Try the parser (requires credits)

What is IRS Code 740?

Plain-English definition: IRS Code 740 means the IRS issued a refund and it was returned as undeliverable (for example, a rejected direct deposit or a paper check returned by the postal service).

Common transcript type
Account Transcript
Usually appears near
Codes 846, 841, 826
Typical context
Refund delivery failure and returned funds
Client-friendly summary
"Your refund was sent back to the IRS"

When does Code 740 appear?

  • After a refund is issued: Often follows Code 846 (refund issued) once delivery fails.
  • After a rejected direct deposit: Closed/invalid account or bank rejection sends funds back to the IRS.
  • After undeliverable mail: A paper check can be returned by USPS due to address issues.

What does Code 740 usually signal?

If this appears alone

The transcript is showing the undeliverable event, but the reversal/reissue/offset actions may not have posted yet. Expect to see follow-up codes if the IRS cancels, credits back, reissues, or offsets the refund.

If this appears with Code 806 or 766/768

Those codes represent credits. If Code 740 appears in the same period, focus on the refund delivery path: confirm whether credits were applied as expected and whether a refund was actually issued (Code 846) and then returned (740).

If this appears with Code 290 or 300

A balance change can complicate refunds. Review sequence and amounts to see whether the refund amount changed, was reduced, or was reversed before/after the undeliverable return event.

If this appears with Code 570

A hold can overlap with refund activity. If 740 posts, the key takeaway is still delivery failure and returned funds. Use adjacent dates/codes to determine whether the hold preceded the issuance or appeared after the return.

What should a tax professional do next?

  1. Confirm context: Map the timeline around Codes 846 and 740 (dates, amounts, and any follow-up codes like 841, 826, or a new 846).
  2. Validate with client: Verify mailing address history and direct deposit details, and ask whether any bank rejection or undeliverable mail notices exist.
  3. Communicate clearly: Provide a short written summary (what happened, what the IRS currently controls, and what you’ll watch for next: reissue, offset, or cancellation/credit-back).

Example: how this looks in a parsed report

Below is a simplified view of how Code 740 appears in a client-ready transcript report with context:

Refund delivery timeline
Code 846 – Refund issued
Date: 04/12/2024
Code 740 – Undeliverable refund (returned)
Reason: Bank rejected deposit / check returned
Code 841 – Refund canceled (amount credited back)
Next: Watch for reissue (new 846) or offset (826)

FAQ

What does IRS Code 740 mean?

IRS Code 740 indicates an issued refund was returned to the IRS as undeliverable (for example, a rejected direct deposit or a paper check returned by the postal service).

Does Code 740 mean my client's refund is approved?

It means a refund was issued and then failed delivery. The next step is figuring out what happened after the return (credit-back via 841, offset via 826, or reissue via a new 846).

How do I turn this into a client deliverable?

Generate a branded transcript report and include it as a consult deliverable. Local parsing, instant results, no upload needed.
